Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The interviews describe an invoice approval process. Lets identify all the steps, roles, decisions, and artifacts. First, list all tasks mentioned: - Invoice arrives by email typically. Input: invoice. - Check if invoice has a valid PO number. Performed by Accounts Payable AP clerk Mary. If no PO, send back to the supplier requesting more details. This is a decision: PO present? If not, then communicate with supplier to get PO. That is an exception path. But note: after sending back, maybe the invoice returns? They might resubmit? Not fully described; probably the process ends for that invoice until supplier corrects. - If has PO, log it into accounting system by AP clerk. - Then forward it to purchasing department to confirm receipt of goods services. Actually, Mary says: After logging it, I forward it to the purchasing department to confirm that the goods or services were actually received. So task: forward to Purchasing likely an email? Or system notification. Role: AP clerk sends to Purchasing.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: From Dans perspective, after his confirmation, he assumes Mary moves it to manager for final approval. From Carlos manager: He gets notification after the invoice has been matched to a PO and Dan confirms that everything is okay. So both matching and confirmation are required before manager approval. That suggests matching is a separate step, likely performed by AP Mary. So the flow: After Purchasing confirmation, AP matches in system; if matches, then to manager; if not, loop back.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Now, note that Mary sends back to supplier if no PO, but Rita mentions she works on invoices without PO to create retrospective PO. This might be an alternative path when the supplier is unable to provide a PO? Possibly if there is no PO but the goods services were received informally, then they need to create a PO retroactively. That might be after initial rejection? Or maybe sometimes the invoice arrives with no PO but its for an informal service, and Mary sends it back; if supplier cant provide PO, maybe they escalate? Or Mary might escalate to Rita? Mary didnt say that; she says she sends back. So the Rita case might be for invoices that have a PO but not matching, or for special circumstances where they bypass the initial check? Possibly Marys description is the standard flow, but in practice some invoices are sent to Rita for resolution. We can treat these as separate exception handling: If no PO and its for an informal service, the process might go to Rita, perhaps after supplier cant provide? Not stated. However, we can note that if the invoice has no PO, it is returned to supplier as per Clerk. However, in some cases e.g., informally contracted services, the AP Supervisor intervenes to either create a retrospective PO or reject the invoice. So we can note variation.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: I propose to outline as: 1. Start: Invoice received. 2. Task: Check PO validity AP Clerk. Gateway: Does invoice have a valid PO number? - No: Two possible variations: a) Typically, return invoice to supplier requesting PO details AP Clerk. This may lead to re-submission later implicitly back to start. b) In some cases e.g., informal services, escalate to AP Supervisor for handling AP Supervisor decides to create retrospective PO or reject. - Yes: Proceed to next step. 3. Task: Log invoice into accounting system AP Clerk. 4. Task: Forward invoice to Purchasing for confirmation AP Clerk. 5. Task: Purchasing confirms receipt and validates invoice Purchasing Officer. ... 10. Task: AP Clerk schedules invoice for payment. End event: Invoice paid.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now, to ensure clarity, we might want to avoid overcomplicating with too many loops; we can consolidate the loops: essentially there is a validation loop that can involve Purchasing, AP, APS, SRM, etc. Another nuance: Mary mentions that after logging invoice, she forwards it to Purchasing for confirmation. Then after confirmation, she matches. But we have two validation points: Purchasing validation and AP matching. It might be that the AP matching is the primary control, and Purchasing validation is a prerequisite. In some processes, the matching is automated and the Purchasing step is to confirm receipt. Well keep both as per interviews.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Conflicts: - Missing PO handling: Mary says she sends back to supplier. Rita says she handles invoices with no PO by creating retrospective PO. Consolidation: We note two possible paths, depending on circumstances. - The exact sequence after Purchasing confirmation: Mary does matching; Dan doesnt mention matching. Well keep matching as per Mary and Carlos who mentions matching. So its consistent. - The point of involvement of Supplier Relationship Manager: Karen says she is looped in if needed; not part of the standard flow. Well note that as a support role. - The managers rejection path: Not detailed; we note it goes back to AP.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, check if there are any parallel activities: Not really. Also, note that after the manager approves, it goes to scheduling. There is no further approval. Now, about end events: We have two possible ends: Invoice Paid scheduled and Invoice Rejected at various points. We could also have an end where invoice is returned to supplier and never processed? That is also a rejection essentially. We can note that. Now, the model includes loops back to steps; we need to ensure that loops are clearly indicated. They are.
